message: Normally I simply do something like this

So I've been wondering about the best way to basically fast-forward my local master branch when I pull in changes from a remote repo without having to check out my local master branch.
git checkout branch_im_working_on
no, but you can move the master branch without being on it to point to remote_branch instead

np
yeah, I've always felt dirty any time I have a branch point directly at a remote branch
otherwise you need the working directory for the merge in case there are any issues with the merge
it needs to use your index and working directory to do basically any actual merge
if you wanted to be clever and you do it a lot, you could use the git-new-workdir script to always have a workdir just for master elsewhere and use that for doing the upstream merges

whats your reason for not wanting to leave your current branch?  uncommited changes? Do a stash, switch to master, pull/merge/etc, switch to prev working branch, do a stash pop - back to the spot you were 2 minutes ago.
it would be nice to type one command instead of 4 or 5 commands, but I understand why it's not really possible (or reasonable)
@ObsidionStorm yes, I've been using stash this whole time... it's more just laziness... :)
